information.title: Definition
information.description: India follows a parliamentary system of government, where the executive is responsible to the legislature. This system is based on the Westminster model of the United Kingdom.

information.title: Features
information.description: Key features include a nominal and real executive, majority party rule, collective responsibility of the executive to the legislature, leadership of the Prime Minister, and a bicameral legislature.

information.title: Nominal vs Real Executive
information.description: The President is the nominal executive (head of state), while the Prime Minister is the real executive (head of government). The Prime Minister and Council of Ministers exercise actual power.

information.title: Majority Party Rule
information.description: The political party or coalition with a majority in the Lok Sabha forms the government. The leader of this party/coalition usually becomes the Prime Minister.

information.title: Collective Responsibility
information.description: The Council of Ministers is collectively responsible to the Lok Sabha. This means the entire Council resigns if it loses the confidence of the Lok Sabha.

information.title: Bicameral Legislature
information.description: India has a bicameral legislature consisting of the Lok Sabha (House of the People) and the Rajya Sabha (Council of States). The Lok Sabha is the more powerful house.

information.title: Question Hour
information.description: During Question Hour, Members of Parliament can ask questions to ministers about their respective ministries. This ensures accountability of the executive to the legislature.
